sentences: [This reference guide is for the Tinellbian languages that descend from High Lulani
Lulani and its descendants were taken into each of the Ptokan worlds by the Guozu
Created by Queen Loren on Mala Ptokonoi
I have been interested in language and linguistics since at least the age of 10
I remember making up words when I was quite young
In fact the High Lulani word dates from that time
When I decided to write a novel a constructed language conlang was an obvious prospect for inclusion in the background information
I had the beginnings of what was to be the Ptokan language and the language of the Fezhlê
The latter was once designed as a daughter language of Ptokan but it had some features mostly phonological that seemed to come from an earlier language
Originally intended to be a phonology sketch Lulani has expanded greatly into a language in its own right
So much so in fact that Ptokan and Fezhlê have been forced to change somewhat to adapt
The Tinellbian languages are a range of constructed languages as befits the constructed universe of Tinellb
In that world the ancestor language was created by Queen Loren of the Ptokonoi and then evolved naturally as different groups of people moved through space time and reality
[Consonants are differentiated by manner and place of articulation and by word-internal gemination
This table shows the consonants phonemically using the International Phonetic Alphabet
Where it differs from IPA the transliteration is given in <triangular brackets>
Capital or geminate glottal stops are transliterated with <ʔ>
ʔusu — capitalised glottal stop at beginning of sentence
ʔallisi — capitalised glottal stop for proper noun Alice
Stops are differentiated by voicing although voiced consonants tend to be rarer than their voiceless counterparts
The voiced stops are fully voiced word-internally and partially voiced word-initially
Voiced geminate stops are given breathy voice
Voiceless stops are lightly aspirated which is suppressed in voiceless geminate stops
Geminate stops are held for approximately twice as long as non-geminate stops
In fast speech they can approach the affricates and
The glottal stop is on e of the most common sounds
Non-geminate glottal stops are often suppressed between unstressed vowels
The second of a geminate glottal stop becomes a palatal approximant
There are nasal consonants at each of the places of articulation of the plosives
However the palatal nasal is only found when geminating the alveolar nasal
Geminate nasals are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates
When geminated this sound is palatal and laminal
The liquids are mainly differentiated by laterality
Like nasals approximants are prototypically voiced and geminates are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates
The consonant is lateral and apical
When geminated this sound is laminal and palatal
The consonant is central retroflex and sub-apical
When geminated this sound becomes a trill
Fricatives do not have complete closure of the vocal tract but are formed with enough constriction to bring turbulence to the airstream
The lips remain unrounded for all fricatives unless followed or preceded by a rounded vowel
Geminate fricatives are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates
The fricative is realised as labiodental
The fricative is a voiceless sound
When geminate it is pronounced as a palatal fricative
[As well as the syllabary for most written use there are also special-use syllabaries
One of these encodes more redundancy for use with noisy channels
The other is a non-visual written code for blind and other visually impaired users
[There is a spelling syllabary used for transmitting words across potentially noisy communication channels such as telephone lines
It is also used for communicaing in situations where every syllable is important such as giving names
Each syllable corresponds to a disyllabic word which begins with the same consonant and ends with its vowel
The geminate symbol is represented by the word faʔa language
[There is a tactile syllabary for use by blind and visually-impaired language users
Each cell is three rows by two columns of raised dots
The upper four dots generally denote the consonant with syllables beginning with b d j g f or x being the exceptions
The lowest pair generally denote the vowel
Dot 5 ⠐ by itself is the geminate
Word separation is shown by ⠀ an empty space clause separation by ⠤ the comma and sentence separation by ⠔ the period
Numbers are prefixed with ⠨ the number sign and the first syllable of each number is used
[A verb is a necessary part of any sentence except when making copular sentences
Verbs can be categorised on the basis of how many elements compose them
The class of stem verbs is semi-closed — there are only about 100 pure verbs in the entire language
Stem verbs consist of a single element
In order to extend or specify meaning verbs can be compounded much as a noun can
Compound verbs are however much more common than compound nouns to make up for the relative lack of stem verbs
[The divalent verbs are called transitive and these require an object to complete its meaning
It is possible to elide this object if it is obvious or irrelevant
The subject is the agent and the object is the patient
Unlike those above these verbs involve a fundamental change to their objects
The unmarked argument structure is as follows the oblique arguments for these are the same as for kinetic verbs i
ablative source  dative destination  and direction with pa
As for the core arguments the agent of the movement is the subject  and the patient being moved is the object
These are motive verbs focussing on movement to the destination
The agent may be moved into the dative position since it is identical to the destination
lit “ I own it to me
An animate source may be swapped with the patient i
the ablative becoming an object and vice versa
gi     to pick up; to carry
These are motive verbs focussing on movement away from a source
Similarly to dative motive verbs the agent can be placed in ablative position as they are identical to the source
lit “ I’ve lost it from me
With similarity again to the dative verbs an animate destination may be swapped with the patient i
with the dative becoming an object and vice versa
These act like the transitive counterpart of the adjectival verbs i
the patient as the subject  the cause in ablative and the experiencer in dative
The additional object  which makes these transitive is an abstract noun that refers to a quality or attribute or an inanimate noun that refers to an actual substance or energy being released
The precise verb is chosen by whether the ‘radiation’ is physical or subtle in nature
Hifu - mari ba’u xi huba ra’u
“Does this house seem important to you
These verbs can also be used to signify the patients resemblance to something else
In this case the other item or person is governed by the adposition ka     as
These verbs require that both their objects and subjects are animate
These verbs take an activity as an object
These can take the form of pure nouns
“The cow stopped its eating of the grass
tapu to look forward to; to enjoy
[Ambitransitive verbs can be used with or without an argument in the object position
These verbs deal with the subject’s ability to perceive stimuli
with no direct or dative object they refer to a general ability to use that sense
When used with a direct object  this denotes a conscious effort at perception
When used with a dative object this instead lacks that effort
The communication itself is the object  and the recipient is dative
Indirect speech is signified by a complement object
Kimilli jusi ’i li lu’i lulani ru
Kimilli jusi ’i li lu’i lulani ru
“The king told him he loved the queen
Directly reported communication is separated from the main clause by a comma and may be put on either side
In this case the recipient may be in either the object position or dative
This argument structure can also be used without a specific communication
“The king said ‘hello’ / spoke to the queen
They can be used in three different ways
The most basic use for an adposition is prefixed to a noun to signify where the action is taking place with relation to a reference
Their nature as a prefix continues to apply even when the noun is already case-marked
As a Nominal or Verbal Modifier
Adpositions can be used to form compound nouns
Adpositions can be used independently to show the position of the action relative to the speaker or the direction in which the action proceeds
Unlike other adverbs these are placed before or instead of the auxiliary
The auxiliary must appear to support an adverbial adposition in copular clauses
“The minister is usually having a drink around now
This list includes both relative and absolute terms
These can be used to refer to locations in either space or time
These can only be used to refer to locations in space
[Suffixes can be used to derive new word from existing vocabulary
A suffix beginning with a vowel replaces the final vowel of the base
These derive words within a class i
a noun from a noun or a verb from a verb
The augmentative -aku   is most often attached to nouns to reference something large or important
It is rarely used for people
The diminutive -ini   is used to form words which reference something small or unimportant
When used with animate nouns it creates a word for the young of non-sapient creatures
However with sapient creatures this word is obscene
The honorific -fi   confers a nuance of sacredness upon a base word
The pair -tu’i   and -da   are used to highlight the positive and negative aspects of a word respectively
These derive nouns from other nouns
The above table shows the suffixes used for deriving nouns between different animacy classes
An animate noun is derived from an inanimate noun by the suffix -rra
Both -sa   and -ri   derive an animate noun from an abstract noun however these are not predictable
For instance note the difference between dis·sa     youth and dissuri     stranger
The -ri   suffix also denotes people from a particular place
The suffix -di   derives an inanimate noun from something abstract and -ja   does the opposite
The suffix -li   derives nouns which are somehow distinct from their stem
The names of parts of the body are derived using -kku   on either nouns or verbs
The animate giver of the inanimate or abstract base is denoted by -mi
The feminine and masculine are denoted by -qi and -kati respectively however they are infrequently used
These are only applied to verbs
The suffix -ni   is used to derive inceptive verbs
The suffix -ulu   denotes reversal of an action and can only be applied to stem verbs
The repetition marker -tuni   has similar form and meaning to the full verb tuni     repeat
The augmentative -ssasu   is used specifically for verbs
The infix -ar- is placed before the final vowel of auxiliaries and denotes an end to the action described by the sentence
There are two kinds of negation for adverbs
On the other hand -ma   forms terminatives i
the situation described by the adverb was true in the past but no longer applies
These derive a noun from another part of speech most often a verb
The suffix -qa   derives generic nouns from numerals or alienable genitive pronouns
The suffix -muka   is used with prepositional phrases
Other suffixes in this group are divided into animacy classes
The productive general suffix -’a   derives abstract nouns
The suffix -ci is applied to adjectival verbs
This includes chromatic verbs whence come the name for colours
Application of -ppa   derives terms for times and occasions
The suffix -ahi is used with adverbs
The patientive suffix -du   is applied to stem verbs
The instrumental suffix -ffi   is applied to a verb
The suffix -kku   derives names for parts of the body from verbs or nouns
When applied to a number -ssiji   gives rise to the names of shapes
There are three suffixes for deriving animate nouns from verbs
The suffix -la’i is used with intransitive verbs while -ba and -pu’a derive generic agents and patients respectively
The pair of suffixes -atinna   and -niqqi   derive adverbs from verbs and nouns respectively
[Deixis encompasses words and phrases which rely on an external context to complete their meaning
Once a topic is introduced in a discourse or narrative it can be assumed to be the subject until changed
The two groups of pro-forms are classified on the basis of their semantic properties
Personal pro-forms  otherwise known as definite pro-forms are those that encode case person animacy and topicality
Indefinite pro-forms comprise the remaining deictic terms
[The indefinite pro-forms are sets of deictic words which can be placed into a table
Proximate forms have referents physically or psychologically near the speaker whereas distal forms are used when the referent is far away
Interrogative forms are used in questions and negative forms are used in negative sentences
Universal means “all” or “every” and existential means “some” or “any”
The existential markers are also used in complements
Unlike some personal pronouns these are not marked for animacy and are thus used to represent people animals or things
“To whom did you give the money
This latter example exploits the ability to swap dative and object for motive verbs
Reduplicated indefinite pronouns with suffixed - ta     and are used for emphasis
In most cases derivations from the object noun forms are obvious
Place pronouns are used for locations in any some or all of space time reality and gingla
They can function as adverbial adpositions
“The elephant drank water here” / “The elephant is drinking water now
As opposed to majja   here or now the word miru   here and now is used for a specific point in all four categories of dimension
“The minister is not happy here now on this plane or in this reality
“The minister is not happy under these circumstances
The action terms are pro-verbs which can be used to replace ordinary verbs in sentences
Manner pro-forms are used to refer to the way in which an action is undertaken
They function as modal adverbs in active sentences i
sentences with overt or implied auxiliaries of activity
“Does the king really walk that way
State pro-forms are used as modal adverbs in stative sentences i
sentences with overt or implied auxiliaries of state
They can also function as deteminers
[Conjunctions are a closed class of words which are used to join phrases or clauses together
These conjunctions are used to join words or phrases
They are enclitics on the second and subsequent nouns
These conjunctions are used to join clauses or sentences
They are used as independent words
Coordinating conjunctions are used to separate two matrix clauses
They are placed at the beginning of the second clause
Subordinating conjunctions are used to introduce a dependent clause
See the section on subordinate clauses for syntactical information
These are simply words that do not fit neatly into any other category
content and relative clause introductory markers and
[The standard word order for matrix clauses is
Subject ‐ Auxiliary ‐ Adposition - Oblique ‐ Verb ‐ Object ‐ Adverb
None of these slots are compulsorily filled
If a subject is obvious from context or is the same as that of the immediately prior sentence it can be dropped
The adverb can act as a pro-sentence
As already discussed intransitive clauses do not have objects
Transitive clauses do require an object
Sometimes the object is in an oblique case
Copular sentences do not have a main verb
These sentences are used to show an equivalence relationship between two nouns or to show that one noun is an element of the set described by the other noun
Another use of copular sentences is to tell the location of something in relation to something else
The copular sentence structure for ownership is as follows
It has the possessor in the dative case and the possessum as the subject
The arguments may be swapped without a change in meaning
These example sentences have been given to clarify alignment and the correct use of pronouns with different auxiliaries
As can be seen the only time the transitive case is used for the subject of a clause is in transitive as well as copular sentences using dynamic or iterative auxiliaries
[The first noun in a clause is the subject which is prototypically the agent in transitive sentences and the patient in intransitive sentences
However suffixes can be added to the verb to promote other nouns in the clause other than the genitive
There are three such verbal suffixes which can be stacked however once something has been shifted from the subject position it can’t be promoted again
The passive suffix promotes the object
-’illu   when the last element of a verb is monosyllabic
-ilu   replacing the final vowel if the final consonant is geminated and
-illu   replacing the final vowel of the verb elsewise
The old subject is then marked with the ablative case
A sentence with this marker is intransitive
The demoted item is not compulsory but if it is put in it is the first ablative-marked noun in the new sentence
The ablative suffix promotes the ablative
-ka   when the final consonant of a verb is geminate or
The old subject is demoted to object and the old object is demoted to dative
A sentence with this marker is transitive
The first dative-marked noun in the new sentence is the demoted item
Lulani qixa kalu- kimilli dasi qasa
“The queen ate a fish because of the king
Kimilli qixa ku- qasa dasi -kka lulani
“The king made the queen eat fish
Kimilli qixa kalu- lulani dasi -illu -ka qasa
“The king made the fish get eaten by the queen
The old subject is demoted to object and the old object if any is demoted to dative
A sentence with this marker is transitive
Mulisa ru ku- quxi kuffa laqqu
fool prs;gno dat - mountain give money
“A fool gives money to the mountain
Quxi ru ku laqqu kuffa xa mulisa
“It is to the mountain that fools give money
Quxi ru kalu mulisa kuffa -ilu -xa laqqu
“It is to the mountain that money is given by fools
To promote a adpositional phrase to subject prefix the verb with the adposition
The old subject is demoted to object
The old object if any is demoted to dative
“It was the sand that she sat in
Mihu pi ni - jagaru dasi nukki
“He was eating a strawberry in the sand
Jagaru pi ku- nukki ni - dasi quhu
“It was in the sand that he was eating the strawberry
[The full noun phrase is made up of these components in the following order
The highlighted component denotes the only one that is compulsory i
The hyphens represent the lack of a word space in both the Tinellbian script and the transcription
xiku dasi nukki na gusulumi iv v-vi
xiku dasi nukki na gusu - lumi
“because of everyone who looks at the moon”
“near the two children who had looked after dogs”
the faces of the mothers and the men who left
[The gerund suffix -ru   changes basic verbs into nouns describing the activity
Compound verbs as well as those involving noun incorporation can also be changed like this
pakicu ru   believing to be true
The genitive determiners including -qa    allow for only the subject of the verb to be mentioned
This continues to apply in instances using argument promotion
[This section details particular categories of vocabulary items

The number system in High Lulani uses balanced sesquidecimal base 15  and so numbers are written with the positive digits 1 2 3 4 5 6 and 7  their negative counterparts 1  2  3  4  5  6 and 7 and a zero 0
is used to separate the integer part of the number from the mantissa
A comma  is used in the integer part to separate the digits into groupings of four beginning from the fractional point
Here are the names for the one-digit numbers
The full form qihha     zero is only used when by itself or first in a number or noun phrase
Numbers between 1 7 and 16 are composed of the quasi-prefix sa   and the final two syllables of the number except for salura not sara 12
numbers ending with a single zero use the suffix -hha
All other two digit numbers except for 22  are formed by juxtaposing the tens digit with the units
The word for 22  the exception is ranira
Three- and four-digit numbers are divided into the number of hundreds and the remainder
This remainder is always the last two digits of the number

Other three-digit numbers beginning with a 1 are formed by prefixing this word to the remainder while even larger three- and four-digit numbers append it to the number of hundreds which is then followed by the remainder as a separate word
In any of these cases if the remainder is zero it is left off
When a number is written out in digits each set of four digits from the fractional point makes up a group
The group furthest from the fractional point may not have this full quota of digits
An index marker notes the identity of a particular group
The index marker is composed of the prefix pa-   followed by the number of groups between this one and the fractional point
Positive index numbers are for the integer part of the number and negative index numbers are for the mantissa
The index marker is suffixed to the group word
There is nothing preventing an index-marked number being used within another index marker although the second pa- is usually geminated
There are two ways to read a mantissa
One uses the above method of index markers and the second reads out the digits in pairs or individually
These methods are often combined using index markers for the first digit groups and then continuing to read digits separately
All rational numbers end with a repeating string of digits
For some numbers this string is “0”
In non-zero cases the word tuni     repeat is inserted before the repeating string
The string must be read out with individual digits
There are also numbers for which the repeating string can be cut in half with digits in the second half being the negative of the digits in the first half
For these only the first half is read out with the word mala     reflect inserted
The suffix -ki   separates the numerator from the denominator
Saki   is used if the numerator is 1
There is also a commonly used variant for ½  ’ima
’u     the base of the natural logarithm
“ to the power of times equals one
Ordinal numbers are used to mark position in a line or a list
The first two ordinal numbers are suppletive that is they are not related to their cardinals
All other ordinals are formed by adding the suffix -uju   to the cardinal number
Ordinal and cardinal numbers are used in noun phrases and are inserted between any case markers or adpositions and the noun
Numbers can be suffixed to a noun to denote not the quantity but a quality
The number ra     two can be used in this way to refer to a pair of something
[These are sample texts in High Lulani
[This comes from an early draft of The Coelacanth Quartet – The Crackled Egg
Kurila cani pamilami matta naru ’ala qira’ataqa nigup·pi jagaru pamana
Kurila cani pa - milami matta naru ’ala qira - ’a - ta - qa ni - gupi - pi jagaru pa - mana
think-surroundings again slowly heat rough - - and - in-sit - sand think-realisation
Qōla is becoming slowly conscious again realising the heat and roughness of the sand in which she is sitting
“Corla came back to consciousness slowly the heat and the coarseness of the sand on which she sat penetrating her mind
Kanu ra’u kal·li nicurilluru gupikarafi pi bi’u
Kanu ra’u kalu - li ni - cur - illu - ru gupi - karafi pi bi’u
Her legs are hurting because of sitting enlightened while time passed
Her legs ached from holding the meditative pose for so long
Kifiqa qixa gadibasillu xitaqa lanu gadibasillu ’aditujatihu cani su’a pa
Kifi - qa qixa ga - di - basi - illu xita - qa lanu ga - di - basi - illu ’adi - tuja - tihu cani su’a pa
Three - put-up-cover -  one - put-up-cover -  near-place-abide  self think

One down two to go she thought to herself

Haru - dattu - sa - ’usi - qa Tinalli ’usu nagi dissu - ’ahati surra la - mari ca - karu rika dissu - mici ra’u
With-divine force - - six - Tinellb  feel-happy when do-this - and thus feel-peace
With the Six gods of Tinellb I will be happy when I have done and finished this and thus I am feeling peace
By the Six gods of Tinellb I’ll be glad to finish this and have some peace
Ra’u kikafasa dissu kixina hibu; kal·li kulu’ipu’a nura dukku na kixina
Ra’u kika - fasa dissu kixina hibu; kal·li ku - lu’i - pu’a nura dukku na kixina
Prs;sta over-moment feel grief allow oneself ; - - love - separate must prs;itr grief
She allowed herself to feel grief for a moment; grief from the fact that she must repeatedly be separated from her lover
She allowed herself to feel grief for a moment grief at being continually separated from her beloved
Kuli laru piba kuppu xiku racaxa mihuqa ’usaju’illuru lanu qapi ru palinu qixa surra di jannitiba cani pajagaru milami
Ku - li la - ru piba kuppu xiku raca - xa mihu - qa ’usa - ju’ - illu - ru lanu qapi ru pa - linu qixa surra di janni - tiba cani pa - jagaru milami
Dat - do - most strong hang - - see-collection - - rope think-realisation  because up move-legs  think-absorption surroundings
Because she realises the fact that doing something is the strongest rope to hang his finding on she stands up she assesses her surroundings
Realising that activity was the surest way to finding him again she stood up to take stock of her situation
Bufiqa daru ra’u qapaccafuni harujagaru nacca gupikunaqi jamicussi
Bufi - qa daru ra’u qa - pacca - funi haru - jagaru nacca gupi - kunaqi jami - cussi
Stone - road down-number-without with-sand covering sit-dirt evidentially-touch
A road of stone seems to be sitting on the ground under the covering with numberless sand
Underneath the thin layer of sand she could feel paving stones
Nisa hulu’a ji bigusuli qu rubaqa gusuli ra’u xidu dissillu
Nisa hulu’a ji bi - gusuli qu ruba - qa gusuli ra’u xidu dissu - illu
Only hear - from-people and sense image - people far away feel -
The only things which are heard are not from people and the sense of people felt far away
Only natural sounds could be heard and the sense of human life was far distant
It seems to probably be a road
It is not this condition I hope it is
ʔala - musa ra’u kalu - pa’aka - gi cussi - xa
Sunheat is felt from over her left shoulder
The sun could be felt over her left shoulder
Musa ga - basi - illu - ru nuki migaru ra’u
The covering over of the sun or is it the showing
ʔusu gibi sumika - sija na - kalu ra’u
Am I pointing my body to the east or to the west

Most strong - sense image - life opposite - - sun
The strongest sense of life is from the other side of the sun

Ji li kikami ru cikki gi’a li cu’i kalugupinuru sa’ibassilu ji palinu
Ji li kika - mi ru cikki gi’a li cu’i kalu - gupi - nu - ru sa’i - bassa - ilu ji pa - linu
interval-some telepath and nothing - sit-stop - fix-situation - think-realisation
She doesn’t sense over what distance it is and realises that nothing isn’t fixed from sitting still
She couldn’t tell how far but she realised that nothing was going to be solved by sitting still
Tuhinuhulu nin·niga kibbasu’a qu canisi jannibattaru bataniqqi
Tuhi - nuhu - ulu nina - niga kibba - su’a qu cani - si janni - batta - ru bata - niqqi
Small-folding paper-undo for-guide stick-self and - inc move-time - care-qal
She unfolds her own guide stick and with care starts the time-travel
She unfolded her cane and carefully began following the roadway away from the sun
Chain of days for the buying
The emotional body of Tŗsh projects light
Rannaxi xiku ninali qa kunubitu’afu gi’assa lanu ra’u ga’i gi’a pajiga nallimiqa sulata ninaxatiqa karra lisami’ulata purakassu
Ranna - xi xiku nina - li qa kunubi - tu’afu gi - ’assa lanu ra’u ga’i gi’a paji - ga nallimi - qa sula - ta nina - xati - qa karra lisa - mi’ula - ta pura - kassu
Glory-showing for - down - land-plain carry-goods time that is fruit-black cheese - goat-and for-flour - wheat paper-reed-and change-buy
A glory-having time for the carrying down of goods down to the plain-lands that is trade blackfruit and the cheese of goats for wheat of flour and reedpaper
That glorious time to take goods down to the flatlands trading olives and goat cheese for wheat flour and papyrus
Li ju’isatadu ximussaru gusutakki qu kugusunulli kikaga’i nura nagi lati
Li ju’i - satadu xi - mussa - ru gusu - takki qu ku - gusu - nulli kika - ga’i nura nagi lati
join-conversation appear-exoticism - person-many and - person-hill for-while separate opportunity
An opportunity for conversing with many exotic-seeming people and separate from the hillpeople for a while
A chance to meet exotic people and get away from the hillfolk for a time
Li xi’allaru sula hafinullitaqa ta’i puramilami jagarudacani quhhaqa ta’i lanuqa lati
Li xi - ’alla - ru sula hafi - nulli - ta - qa ta’i pura - milami jagaru - da - cani quhha - qa ta’i lanu - qa lati
appear-familiarity - goat grass-hill-and - scent change-circumstance sand-water-having river - scent - opportunity
An opportunity to change the circumstances from scents of familiar-seeming goats and hillgrass to those of watersand having rivers
A chance to exchange the familiar smells of goat and heath for the scent of the silty river
Quhu nina - li puta ’ita’i - ’assa cani - karu ca - xina - ra
She’s finishing helping her two parents with filling the goods-car
She finished helping her parents fill the wagon
Taku nikamiriqa sula bili padissu kiluquru qixa ca pada kikaxiku ’adi ni’adda ru laruluminisa bili qakunulli jannillu
Taku ni - kamiri - qa sula bi - li pa - dissu kiluqu - ru qixa ca pada kika - xiku ’adi ni - ’adda ru laru - lumi - nisa bi - li qa - ku - nulli janni - nika na saki - mici - illu

She repeatedly helped in the goat pen from the learning to walk and was given permission to repeatedly travel down the hill only over the several recent years in the past
She had helped in the goat pens since she learned to walk but only been allowed to travel down the hills within the last few years
Pi’adu cani du’ikaluhafitisaka kumallijakuqa tu rubasika
Pi’adu cani du’i - kalu - hafi - tisaka ku - malliju - aku - qa tu ruba - sika
d&#x26f ;/ opposite - - field-village - joy-aug - offspring sense image-drv

Warning This section is a work in progress
While High Lulani continued being used in the Palace and its surrounds the living language continued to evolve in the mouths of the people
Warning This section is a work in progress
This table shows the consonants phonemically using the International Phonetic Alphabet
Where it differs from IPA the transliteration is given in < triangular brackets >
The latter change also occurs at the ends of words

Warning This section is a work in progress
To produce the inflected forms simply add the corresponding inflection taking sandhi into account
Warning This section is a work in progress
Warning This section is a work in progress
This page includes a list of changes from High Lulani to Demotic Lulani
A detailed up-to-date list of changes in kept at GitHub  in a Python file that applies these changes to a High Lulani word
Lowering of back vowels before peripheral consonants
Shifting of geminate consonants unvoiced plosive → voiced plosive → voiced fricative
I-mutation of vowels when followed by / / in the next syllable
Palatalisation of alveolar sounds when followed by / /

Elision of unstressed / / followed by 
 consonant cluster reduction
Reduction of remaining unstressed vowels to schwa
This can be transliterated with a lower dot on the affected vowel
From a combination of stress patterns and elision / reduction of unstressed vowels verbs became trigrade
Adjectives developed from verbs originally followed by monosyllabic auxiliaries i
grade one and grade zero verbs
Grade two verbs remained verbs however the meaning of the auxiliaries has shifted
The dative began to take over the functions of the accusative which was thereby dropped
